reviews.review_msg: This prof deters people from linguistics. The classes were extremely boring. His slides are straight from the textbook and he lectures directly off the slides. No point in going, just read the slides and memorize the textbook. Tests obscure, irrelevant details on MC exams. Thinks way too highly of himself.

WORST PROF I'VE HAD YET!!! 0/10, would not recommend. Summarizes textbook & reads off slides in lecture, awful midterms (unnecessarily complicated), and terrible teaching skills! seems more interested in getting students to memorize textbook examples than actually understanding concepts. Do not take a class with this prof!

Slides are taken from textbook and he lectures from them during v. long and dry 3 hours. All exams are MC and while 1st one was easy, the second one was incredibly tricky and obscure. Even with proper studying  I barely passed due to random/tricky questions pulled from textbook. Definitely lost any interest in linguistics and would NOT recommend.

I LOVE YOU MR SOSA !!!!! His free-style teaching method really entertained the whole class. His tests were extremely easy if you followed the lecture. Take home final was a little brutal but it worth the effort at the end! GREAT PROF EVER!!!

Professor Sosa is one interesting man, he goes out of his way to encourage class discussion in a class without tutorials. But his material comes directly from the textbook and the take home midterms are EXTREMELY long (10-11 essay questions each) so if you take his class make sure you have plenty of time to write them the week before. Great class:)

The course is easy to understand.  Midterms are fair because they are take home exam.  Boring class.  He likes picking on favours and only knows their names.  Don't really like him but it's a mark booster course
This course, you should def take!! He's very entertaining and everything learnt from this class is/will be useful at least once in your life time haha. I think he's a genius. lol

Professor Anonby is very passionate and knowledgable about sociolinguistics. However, he is a little disorganized, and some of his ideas are quite obviously biased. He does have a lot of really interesting stories though, and a lot of experience in the field. I would recommend him if you are interested in this area.

Dr. Tchizmarova was a great! I took this class as an elective and didn't know a lot about linguistics, yet she made everything super easy to understand and all of her lectures were super engaging. Tests were moderately hard because they included memorizing super specific details from textbook examples, but other than that the class was great!

The professor is a nice person but not an effective instructor. Exams don't reflect what's taughtâ€”she tests on things mentioned once and not found in slides or the textbook, yet expects detailed answers. Assignment criteria are unclear, and she gets defensive when asked about grading. Not a GPA booster do not take this course if you can avoid it.

Grossly long lectures and projects that make you want to rip your hair out. Multiple choice exams that refer to something mentioned briefly in lectures and randomly assigned group projects in which your group mates decide whether or not you get a good grade. Takes away marks often and inconsistently. 3 hour lectures that melt your brain.

She is a great prof! Make sure you go to every single class to write down all the answers that we have discussed during class! Her exams are easy and she somehow curved the grades in order to make us to get a better mark!

I can tell Larysa is very passionate about linguistics and makes the class as easy as possible. And by easy, I mean she literally gives you questions at the start of every class on paper, with a select number on the MT, written verbatim.
Not a good professor. Doesn't teach well, doesn't encourage questions. Poor performance.

Lectures are all textbook based but she does 10% participation so you're showing up to have the textbook read to you for 3 hours. When someone asks her a question she's almost defensive all the time and her answer doesn't help. Has a strong accent.

She is horrible. She is not only difficult to understand, but her exams are just as incomprehensible. Her questions are so vague but she looks for such specific answers! Her grading methods are disgusting, honestly. She says you can "justify answers" but it's really just to waste time. And, I'm sure it's been mentioned: VOICE IS ANNOYING! Bad prof!

She is a very nice woman, with a lot of patience for those who speak out and/or outwardly make inappropriate comments. However, her notes are directly from the book, are posted on WebCT AND the lectures were taped...little reason to show up to class.I was one of the few who didn't make a habit of skipping. Many complained about her heavy accent.

Hated the short podcast question assignments, says she listens to feedback but doesn't budge despite various complaints about the format. I just skip through the podcast until I find the assignment questions, big waste of time. She is knowledgeable but does not give a lot of actual help to students. Only take the course if you have time for this.

I was really excited to take this class because of the subject matter, but I've been quite disappointed in the way that she structures her material.
There are no clear instructions or rubric for any of the assignments she gives (5 every week) other than to listen to a podcast that may or may not give some direction.

Professor Hilgendorf was frustrating to learn from. She gives at least five small assignments each week, plus online chapter discussions. She gives zero rubrics, solid criteria or word counts for these assignments. You never know what she wants. Way too intense for a first-year course. Interesting subject but not worth learning about from her.

Way too many assignments a week (4-7), hours of podcasts per week and attendance was mandatory. I found it frustrating if a student were to miss a class it would be a problem, but office hours were cancelled more than once.

Class consisted of 3 midterms, online discussion and in-class assignments. Midterms were mc and were way too long tbh since each question you were literally given a paragraph to read and the time given wasn't enough. Online discussions were weirdly graded as it seemed like it was graded on "effort" and to get 90+, I had to spend at least 2-3 hours

LING160 had 2 canvas discussions due per week, 48 hours apart, which needed at least 2 hrs in order to get at least a 90% grade per discussion, not to mention the extra hour to read the chapter first, totalling 6 hours just in homework, not to mention the 3 hours of lecture which involve in-class assignments. Never worked this hard for a 100 level

she didnt finish the material due to her personal reason, so she gives us two writing assignment. I mean she gives us extra exercise and homework all the time during the class. However, she never tell you how she grade the exercises. She always talk about her germany story and make some question on the exam. WHO CARE?

She passionate but her teaching style is just too traditional to be interesting. Read the textbooks for main ideas, her lectures only provide additional information, examples mentioned in lectures would usually appear on the exam. Multiple choice exams, super long and tricky. Attendance is graded.

Meh, I thought I would have liked this course more. Dr. HIlgendorf was okay, the beginning was slow and dry. Unless you can pull out a 101 examples about your multilingualism and how you speak Punjabi at home, Mandarin at work, and English and Spanish at school and don't mind speaking in front of your 80 person lecture, " u gunna have a bad time".

Overall she was decent.  Good lecturer, but slow.  Three MC exams (25% each, mostly textbook based), a graded online discussion per chapter, 5% attendance (she takes roll so don't skip).  One thing to note was that she assigned two group projects that weren't on the syllabus, with about a week to complete each.  Also, her grading scale is high.

Very clear and engaging lectures. She is understanding and available for help. Attendance is taken. Tests are multiple choice and based on the textbook. Online discussion participation based on textbook  is required and graded. Material was very interesting. Loved it and would recommend!

Irina is an engaging professor. Her class was always interesting which made it easy to attend 3 hr lectures. Lots of group work and assignments but they're really easy-mostly for completion and to help relate to the material which essentially helps with the exams. The exams were the most difficult because it all application questions.
Her lectures are pretty fun but the attendance is mandatory
The course is very interesting and the prof is enthusiastic.

This was the BEST class especially with the prof. We didnt really need to buy the textbook because he teaches so well everything sticks in your head. And you can use the PowerPoints to study. It is a very engaging class and you can easily relate it to your life. You have online discussions every week which are easy and interesting. Fun lectures!!!

Less workload !! There are many small group discussions during the lectures. I found that it is good for me to remember the course material, he is not a tough grader for the midterm and final, you will need to give short answers in each question, as long as you can show him the main idea and elaborate the details for your points, you will be fine.
